results.title: Their bridge again: restoration of the Tasman Bridge
results.brief_description: On January 5th, 1975, the Tasman Bridge in Hobart, tragically collapsed, sinking a ship and her cargo and dismembering sections of the bridge in seconds. For 2 1/2 years Hobart was without a central road link across the river, whilst reconstruction work was underway. This was a test of skill of the engineers, and the restoration was a great challenge to all concerned. Work on the project is shown through the various stages until final completion.

results.title: Thee Films: 1950's - 1960's
results.creator_credit: Antony Balch, William S. Burroughs and Psychic Television
results.brief_description: Five short films featuring the poetry and prose of the Beat writers; William Burroughs, Brion Gyson and Ian Somerville. Filmed in New York City, Paris and Tangiers, the films do not use narrative but rather incorporate avant-garde and experimental film techniques. Burroughs’ poetry, and his commitment to homo-eroticism and heroin use, feature prominently in the films. “William buys a parrot”, “The cut-ups” and “Bill and Tony” last a few minutes whilst “Towers open fire” and “Ghosts at no. 9 (Paris)” are longer films. The last film is an hour excerpt of a longer five hour epic.

results.title: Theatre: getting your act together
results.brief_description: Presents a behind-the-scenes look at the theatre and the roles of the playwright, director, actor and theatre production staff. Designed to promote students’ interest in the theatre and to provide them with an insight into the workings of two professional theatre companies - The Melbourne Theatre Company and Sydney’s King O’Malley Theatre Company. The program is divided into five sections: 1 What is theatre? 2 The playwright in society. 3 In rehearsal. 4 The performance. 5 Theatre in society.

results.title: The Zoo
results.brief_description: A visit to one of the world’s largest and most modern zoos, the Chicago Zoological Park. Animals are observed in areas simulating their natural habitat. Features polar and kodiak bears, lions, tigers, kanagaroos, baboons and a variety of familiar and not so familiar animals.

results.title: The Zertigo Diamond Caper
results.brief_description: The police are baffled when the world’s largest diamond is stolen from its top security museum display. Jeffrey, a 12 year old blind boy is present when the crime is committed. His mother, a museum administrator, is one of only three people with access to the diamond through the voice-print-security system, and she’s the chief suspect. To complicate matters, Jeffrey’s divorced father is assigned to the case and ignores Jeffrey’s crime-solving efforts. It’s up to Jeffrey to piece together the puzzling clues.

results.title: The Zebra in your stable
results.brief_description: Why do zebras have stripes? Why do broncos buck? How do horses manage to stand so still for hours? The horse. Its power and grace has stirred the human emotions for hundreds of years. From its exotic Arabian relatives to the show performances of the perfect thoroughbred, man’s love for the horse is undying. But how well does man understand these equine creatures? In this captivating documentary, Desmond Morris shows that underneath the stripes, the wild exteriors and the tutored perfection, different breeds are much the same animal. A horse lovers delight, this unique video journeys from the African plains to the wild Navaho desert, exploring the nature and habits of all breeds of horse, showing the wild animal that lurks beneath the domesticity.

results.title: The Yugoslav experiment
results.brief_description: This film uses newsreels and interviews to trace the history of Yugoslavia and shows the present day situation, (of 1977). Emphasis is placed on the Yugoslav economy, the agricultural and industrial systems, tourism and education.

results.title: The Youngest WAAAF in the service
results.creator_credit: Jean Williamson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: For Jean Williamson, her time at the Women’s Auxiliary Australian Airforce was new and exciting and, much to her disappointment, short. She joined a few months shy of the end of the war. Still, as she looks back through an album of memories, she reflects fondly on friends made, good times and meeting her husband Noel. She also considers how at that time she wasn’t aware she was an Indigenous Australian. When she found out, she responded by becoming heavily involved in the Indigenous community. Despite her pale complexion, Jean Williamson proudly declares her black heart.
